name: Long-fruited Anemone
leaves: Compound;  Whorl of 4-9 leaves at mid-stem.

name: Trailing Arbutus
leaves: oval. Rounded or pointed at the ends. Hairy.

name: Arethusa
leaves: not developed until after the plant flowers.

name: Amethyst Aster
latin_name: Symphyotrichum x amethystinum(formerly Aster x amethystinus)

name: Bog Aster
leaves: decreasing in size up the stem
habitat: bogs. In the region north of Barrie & south of North Bay
and north of Sault Ste. Marie.

name: Calico Aster
habitat: Meadows;  Fields. Often found at the edge of a field

name: Flat-topped White Aster
leaves: with prominent veins. They are smooth when rubbed in one direction
habitat: Moist Meadows;  Moist woods and swamps

name: Heart-leaved Aster
leaves: with a very deep cleft at the base of the leaf. Upper stem leaves are still somewhat heart-shaped
or have a much shallower cleft - resemble leaves of Arrow-leaved Aster (Symphyotrichum urophyllum). Conspicuously & jaggedly toothed.
habitat: Fields and Open Areas;  Open woods and edges of woods.

name: Heath Aster
leaves: as in heaths. The upper stem leaves are tipped with a tiny soft spine. Lower leaves often gone by flowering.
habitat: roadsides. Grows in patches as it spreads primarily by runners and roots.

name: Large-leaved Aster
leaves: upper and lower surfaces smooth or hairy/sticky. Upper stem leaves oval to lance-shaped
gradually smaller higher on the stem.

name: New England Aster
leaves: Clasping stem. Crowded along the stem. Have three prominent veins. Lower leaves have usually disappeared by flowering time. Leaves are toothless. Smell a little bit spicy when crushed.
habitat: Fields and Open Areas;  Open areas

name: Panicled Aster
leaves: lance-shaped. Dead leaves along the stem tend to be very curly
as in a spiral. Lower leaves usually gone by flowering. The biggest leaves are in the upper middle of the stem.

name: Smooth Aster
leaves: not toothed. Clasping stem a little.

name: Whorled Aster
leaves: Simple;  Leaves appear to be in a whorl. Upper leaves are larger than lower leaves. Coarsely toothed

name: Red Baneberry
leaves: toothed. More dissected than White Baneberry (Actaea pachypoda).

name: White Baneberry
leaves: toothed. Less dissected than Red Baneberry (Actaea rubra).

name: Bunchberry
leaves: Entire;  Whorled on one tier. Occasionally on two tiers. Typical Dogwood style leaves.
habitat: Forests;  Common in woods everywhere. Also in bogs.

name: Calypso
leaves: Entire;  Single round basal leaf which may not be present when plant is flowering.

name: Common Cinquefoil
leaves: Palmate leaves - 5 leaflets toothed for 3/4 of their length.
habitat: Fields and Open Areas;  Fields and open woods.

name: Three-toothed Cinquefoil
habitat: Fields and Open Areas;  This is a northern species. Rocky & sandy areas.

name: Yellow Clintonia
leaves: Entire;  Two or three broad basal leaves.

name: Golden Corydalis
leaves: Lobed;  Some sources show much more finely divided leaves than others.

name: Cowwheat
leaves: Opposite. Often the upper leaves have a few pointed teeth.

name: English Daisy
habitat: Fields and Open Areas;  Grows in lawns.

name: Lakeside Daisy
habitat: Fields and Open Areas;  Open alvar habitats.

name: Narrow-leaved Gentian
habitat: Wet Areas;  Damp woods and wet meadows.

name: Blue-stemmed Goldenrod
habitat: Fields and Open Areas;  Open forests

name: Grass-leaved Goldenrod
habitat: Wet Areas;  Open fields - most soil.

name: Gray Goldenrod
habitat: Fields and Open Areas;  Very dry open fields.

name: Late Goldenrod
habitat: Fields and Open Areas;  Open areas

name: Sharp-leaved Goldenrod
habitat: Fields and Open Areas;  Forest & field.

name: Stiff-leaved Goldenrod
habitat: Fields and Open Areas;  Open fields.

name: Northern Jointweed
habitat: Fields and Open Areas;  Dry sandy areas.

name: Pink Lady's Slipper
habitat: Wet Areas;  Dry or moist woods
usually under Oak or Pine trees.

name: Trout Lily
leaves: One or two per plant. Stiff
3-8" long. Mottled like a trout fish skin (hence the name).

name: White Trout Lily
leaves: One or two per plant. Stiff
3-8" long. Mottled like a trout fish skin (hence the name).

name: Purple Loosestrife
leaves: Grow in pairs or sometimes whorls of three.

name: Sea Lungwort
habitat: Fields and Open Areas;  Usually seashores. But can also be found in sandy areas.

name: Mayapple
leaves: umbrella-like. Flowering plants have two large leaves
habitat: Forests;  Forests. Sometimes these plants carpet the forest floor. Sometimes they grow in open fields as well.

name: False Mermaid
habitat: Forests;  Wet woods and stream valleys.

name: Fringed Polygala
leaves: crowded near the top of the short stem.

name: One-Flowered Pyrola
leaves: Basal rosette of small roundish evergreen leaves. These are the only leaves.

name: Green-leaved Rattlesnake Plantain
leaves: Only leaves are in a bassal rosette. Green leaves
each with a whitish stripe down the middle. Smooth.

name: Rock Sandwort
height: Up to 10 cm (4 in);  A small low plant.

name: Wild Strawberry
leaves: Toothed;  The terminal tooth of the leaves is much smaller than the ones beside it. The leaflets have stems (petioles).

name: Woodland Strawberry
leaves: Toothed;  Terminal tooth of leaflets is equal to or larger than the adjacent teeth. Leaflets don't have stems (petioles).

name: Black Swallowwort
habitat: Fields and Open Areas;  Open areas

name: Pale Swallowwort
habitat: Fields and Open Areas;  Open areas

name: White Swallowwort
habitat: Fields and Open Areas;  Open areas

name: Thimbleweed
leaves: Opposite/Whorled;  Whorl of 3 leaves at mid-stem.

name: European Common Twayblade
habitat: Wet Areas;  Open woods and edges.
